posts.title: Celebrate Bronx Week Year-Round
posts.text: Looking for new ways to celebrate Bronx Week? Check out these free resources!

posts.title: The Bronx Library Center Podcast: Episode 8
posts.text: In this episode, Rich and Herb dive into National Poetry Month and interview Adult Services Librarian Dana Bello of the Countee Cullen branch in Harlem.

posts.title: The Bronx Library Center Podcast: Episode 7
posts.text: In this episode, Rich and Herb dive into Women's History Month and interview the Bronx Library Center's Managing Librarian, Melissa Davis.

posts.title: The Bronx Library Center Podcast: Episode 6
posts.text: In this episode we dive into Isabel Wilkerson's 'The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration' and Ernest Hemingway's 'The Old Man and the Sea'. Then we interview Mrs. Cheryl Shackelton-Hawkins, a former NYPL librarian who guided us into the world of Caribbean and African American genealogy.

posts.title: Laura Alvarez's Woman Being Project
posts.text: Some of the key issues that Alvarez's work tackles are breastfeeding in public, fertility, motherhood, and genetics.

posts.title: Evelyn Ray's "Let's Celebrate Women!" Online Exhibit
posts.text: The exhibit centers on mixed media art created to uplift women from all walks of life and explores female identity and multicultural shared experiences.

posts.title: Arturo A. Schomburg: su vida y legado
posts.text: Schomburg fue uno de los principales coleccionistas de literatura Negra, narrativas de esclavos, obras de arte y materiales de la diáspora: un titán de la preservación.

posts.title: Pura Belpré: narradora de cuentos de la biblioteca
posts.text: Las sesiones de teatro de títeres de Pura eran tan queridas en las aulas y bibliotecas de toda la ciudad de Nueva York que los cuentos eventualmente se publicaron como libros para niñas y niños.

posts.title: Virtual Citizenship Study Groups at NYPL
posts.text: Are you studying to become a US citizen? Join us online for interactive weekly study groups.

posts.title: Evelyn Ray's Virtual Art Class for Seniors
posts.text: For artist Evelyn Ray and the senior citizens who participate in her art classes, the pandemic has been a trying time that forced them to seek camaraderie and recreation using unconventional means.

posts.title: Pura Belpré: Library Storyteller
posts.text: Belpre’s storytelling skills and puppeteering became major community attractions that showcased her grandmother’s folkloric tales during story sessions.

posts.title: Arturo A. Schomburg: His Life and Legacy
posts.text: Schomburg was one of the world’s premiere collectors of Black literature, slave narratives, artwork, and diasporic materials—a titan of preservation.

posts.title: Olga Ayala's Crowns = Coronas Paintings
posts.text: Her Crowns = Coronas exhibit featured ten pieces that represent the artist’s varied interests in Nuyorican culture, African heritage, and Santeria.

posts.title: Artist Frank Pellot's "Borikén Presente" at Bronx Library Center
posts.text: Now showing at the BLC's Latino and Puerto Rican Cultural Center through December 2, paintings that capture the vibrant culture and people of "la isla del encanto".

posts.title: The Black Feminist Project at the Bronx Library Center
posts.text: On September 14, the Bronx Library Center hosted Not Just Talk: Black Womxn Matter, an event that treated NYPL patrons to stimulating discussion on the state of feminism in 21st century United States. Here are the day's details.

posts.title: Thinking Big: Art for Seniors with Parkchester Enhancement Program
posts.text: Creating art can be a soothing, collaborative, enriching exercise, as this group of seniors found out. With a donation of canvas, acrylic paint, and brushes (and time), flowing streams and clouds awaited...

posts.title: Remembering Lucas Silverio
posts.text: A Bronx Library Center staffer recalls a heroic friend and colleague.

posts.title: Spanish Pulp Fiction at the Bronx Library Center
posts.text: One of the hidden gems at the BLC is in the 4th floor Reference department: a little trove of Spanish-language pulp fiction novels, filled with plenty of gunslingers and gore.

posts.title: 2019 Reforma Northeast Mini-Conference
posts.text: Librarians, scholars, and publishers gathered to share their newest projects, and NYPL presented the Book Box Project, focused on providing free books to patrons throughout the Bronx.

posts.title: Bronx History at the Bronx Library Center: The Morris Park Racecourse
posts.text: Before Belmont Park opened in 1905, the jewel of horse racing in New York City was a 1 1/2-mile racecourse in the Bronx. Find out how people (and horses) made their way to the track, and what became of the racecourse's land.

posts.title: Bronx History at the Bronx Library Center: What's in a (Street) Name?
posts.text: Have you ever looked up at your street sign and wondered how your block got its name? A 522-page research revelation describes the avenues, streets, and neighborhoods throughout the Bronx.

posts.title: Bronx History at the Bronx Library Center: Discovering Freedomland
posts.text: It was a haven of entertainment for hundreds of thousands of visitors from 1960 to 1964. Discover the $65 million amusement park that once lived right in the Bronx.
